title: 105_s274
content: The Act may be cited as the "Northern Border States Council Act" and establishes a council. The Northern Border States-Canada Trade Council is established with 24 members from specific states appointed by state governors. The Secretary of Commerce appoints two members from each state to serve on the Council, with appointments made from nominees submitted by the Governor. Members serve terms aligned with the Governor's term, vacancies are filled promptly, and the Council must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairperson, and a majority of members constitute a quorum for decision-making. The Council selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members, who serve for 2 years unless their term is terminated early. A majority of members constitute a quorum for hearings. The Council is responsible for specific duties. The Council's duties include advising on US-Canada trade policies, taxation, regulation of cross-border trade, and potential trade barriers due to customs or immigration laws. The Council advises on US-Canada trade policies, taxation, regulation of cross-border trade, and trade barriers. It monitors trade issues and disputes involving Council-member States and Canada, making recommendations on resolving them. Upon request, it responds to the United States Trade Representative, Secretary, Members of Congress, or Governors of Council-member States. The Council reviews and comments on reports regarding United States-Canada trade, disputes settlement under NAFTA, and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Council established under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade determines if a trade dispute between the United States and Canada is due to actions or inactions of the Canadian government. The term "Council-member State" refers to a state represented on the Council. The Council established under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will submit a report to the President and Congress every 2 years with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Council also has powers outlined in Section 5. The Council, established under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, has powers outlined in Section 5. These powers include holding hearings, receiving evidence, securing information from Federal agencies, using postal services, and accepting gifts or donations. SEC. 6. COUNCIL PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Council serve without compensation, but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Council has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Council without reimbursement, and the Chairperson can also procure temporary and intermittent services. The Chairperson of the Council can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Secretary must provide office space for Council activities and personnel. The Council will terminate 54 months after the enactment of the Act, submitting a final report to the President and Congress 90 days before termination. An amount not exceeding $250,000 is authorized for the Council annually from Department of Commerce appropriations, with funds available until expended.
